comments.author: Mariela Villanueva

comments.text:
Since childhood, my parents flash or wave to let a car in, so I didn't know 
it is unusual in other countries. Most Japanese drivers are very polite and 
do this, but a few of them are aggressive, approaching a car very closely. 
I wish more and more drivers in the world would be more considerate with 
each other.﻿
comments.author: Jun Jun

comments.text: I call it "Arigatou Flash" when I drive there. ﻿

comments.text:
We do that in Venezuela, but using the hand greetings-like sign, and we 
aren't  known not as a "polite" culture.﻿
comments.author: Chris Crocker

comments.text:
I'll flash my headlights at an oncoming car wanting to turn in front of me 
so that they know I am slowing down and giving them enough room to safely 
execute their turn.﻿

comments.text:
Japan has the most irresponsible drivers of anywhere i have been. I've 
never seen so many red lights jumped, the roads are medieval, and there are 
almost no bicycle lanes for the millions on two wheels. No wonder there are 
so many deaths on Japanese roads. The idea that you can turn as a motorist 
when pedestrians are crossing is ludicrous.﻿

comments.author: Steven Flores

comments.text:
日本（にほん）の車（くるま）マナーをご存知（ぞんじ）ですか？
日本は道（みち）を譲（ゆず）ってもらった際、「ありがとう」を言いたい時はハザードを２回（かい）点滅（てんめつ）させます。これは相手（あいて）に対（たい）しての感謝（かんしゃ）の意味（いみ）になるんですよ！
みなさん動画を見てみてくださいね〜♪
http://youtu.be/WfrKFU9z0GQ﻿

道路交通法の建前論はともかく、車を運転する際に必要な心がけは安全に対する適度な緊張感と共に平常心でしょ。
礼儀の問題は当然のこととしても、謝意を示すことで互いに気持ちよく運転を継続できるようにする心の環境浄化は大切だよ。﻿

comments.author: Steve Anderson

comments.text:
I'm a white van driver in London. This is commonplace here. If I let 
somebody in and they don't give a flash of the Hazards, or give me a wave 
it really pisses me off. There's a lot of road rage in the city, myself 
included but this is just common courtesy. I actually feel bad if I forget 
to thank someone like this!﻿
comments.author: Flavius Aetius

comments.text: We do that here in Northern Ireland, I thought everybody does that o.O﻿
comments.author: DINUKA WIJESINGHE

comments.text:
La verdad que no me parece extraño, para mí es algo muy común y pensé que 
se hacía en todo el mundo. Soy de Argentina y aquí lo normal es que suceda 
sobre todo en la ruta dónde incluso los conductores de camiones que al ser 
más grandes y por consiguiente tener mejor visión te avisan con luces 
cunando es seguro sobrepasarlos y luego ambos conductores se hacen señales 
de agradecimiento con las luces.
En la ciudad lo más común es que en vez de las luces se saluden con la mano 
a través de los espejos retrovisores ( el de adelante) y el parabrisas (el 
de atrás).﻿
comments.author: Patricia Fernanda Viola

comments.text:
In many places flashing whit the hazard lights is a way to say "Thank you".
I know it from my father from 20+ years
Im from Bulgaria, East Europe﻿

comments.author: Kei Zhang

comments.text: ドイツでは違反になっちゃうんだ Σ（ﾟдﾟlll）﻿
comments.author: 鈴木かなえ

comments.text:
They are indeed well-mannered, but other than that terrible drivers. 
Starting the signal light when already turning, or when just leaving after 
the traffic light turns green.
Hitting the gas a bit when they see the the traffic light hitting yellow, 
at times still going through the red light just so they don't have to wait 
for the next one. And many other traffic violations that are quite a big 
cause for accidents. I have never seen or heard of anyone getting a ticket 
nor a warning for the above mentioned violations. But I have heard about 
getting tickets at places with a road coming out at a bigger road with 100% 
visibility, but didn't make a small pause at the traffic sign because there 
are no cars/cyclists/pedestrians in sight for at least a hundred meters. 
While the police hide behind a little sign somewhere.

But I think that's a bigger problem with traffic control than actual 
driving ability. As long as the police don't say anything, even though they 
are waiting at the front at a traffic light, then that must mean that it's 
not a violation, therefore you may do it. Seems to be the logic.﻿
comments.author: SkaiSharku

comments.text: This video put a huge smile on my face! thanks ﻿

comments.author: olibenni

comments.author: halomiksa

comments.text:
This is actually quite a common practice for commercial truck drivers in 
the US as well as driving in the snow packed mountains in places like 
Colorado, Washington or Maine. I wouldn't say this is a uniquely Japanese 
thing to do. Perhaps this happens with greater prevalence, and serve as a 
apt example of polite driving in Japan. It may be the combination of waving 
in, hazards, non-aggression that equates to a comparatively more "polite" 
driving experience vs. other countries. ﻿
